page.title: 06"Bowcombe"-Garstons.
page.content: The original land at{Garstons}was purchased in the fourteenth century from the Quarr Abbey estates which covered an extensive area of the Island at that time. The purchaser, who established a farm on the site, was a John Garstons; contemporarily described as a "Man of substance and breeder of rabbits"! Until quite recently the house at Garstons was a farmhouse after which the farm was named, the present house having been built in 1831, and{has the unique {status of being geographically the {most central house in the Island.} The house is now a private residence the farmer having moved his headquarters to nearbye Gatcombe. The present owners sold a guesthouse at Shanklin to "escape from the rat-race to make a dream home in the country." There are Roman remains in the garden.
